Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 500 MHz NMR to Enhance Research and Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), and the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), Professor Lisa Berreau from Utah State University and colleagues Cheng-Wei Chang, Alvan Hengge, Yujie Sun and Jixun Zhan will acquire a 500 MHz NMR spectrometer. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research by postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate students at Utah State University, the USDA Poisonous Plant Research Laboratory, and the regional USU campus at the Uintah Basin. It will also impact outreach activities involving minority student populations.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) advancing metabolic engineering and synthetic biology; (b) understanding the roles of metals in biological systems and developing reagents for biological use; (c) developing new carbohydrate-containing molecules with useful biological activities; (d) understanding the details of phosphate ester hydrolysis reactivity in biological systems; (e) developing new catalysts for water splitting reactivity with relevance to solar energy production; (f) identifying poisonous plant toxins; and (g) advancing natural products synthesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Access to modern high-field nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is essential for research and teaching in chemistry and related fields. This NSF grant provided funds for the acquisition of a new Bruker Avance III HD Ascend 500 MHz NMR spectrometer that was installed in 2015. The instrument is managed by a full time PhD level scientist (Dr. Casey Simons) who is responsible instrument upkeep, maintenance and user training.

Intellectual Merit. The acquisition of the 500 MHz NMR system has enabled ongoing advancements in research in the following areas: (1) metabolic engineering and synthetic biology; (2) understanding the roles of metals in biological systems and developing new reagents for biological use; (3) the development of new carbohydrate-containing molecules with useful biological activities; (4) understanding the details of phosphate ester hydrolysis reactivity in biological systems; (5) developing new catalysts for water splitting reactivity with relevance to solar energy production; (6) identifying poisonous plant toxins; and (7) natural products synthesis. Fifteen scientific publications involving use of the 500 MHz NMR instrument have appeared to date in these areas. Essential to the data included in these publications is the spectral resolution and sensitivity of the 500 MHz NMR instrument.

Broader Impacts. NMR is an indispensable spectroscopic tool in chemistry research, and is an essential component of student training. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in research in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry and related departments (Biological Engineering, Nutrition and Food Science) at Utah State University are trained for independent use of the 500 MHz NMR. Dr. Casey Simons provides technical support and instruction to students running new and/or advanced experiments. Training on the 500 MHz NMR has been incorporated into upper division chemistry courses (Instrumental Analysis and Advanced Synthesis lab), which are taken by all ACS approved undergraduate chemistry majors. Visiting undergraduate summer internship students (~8/year) in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry from regional four-year schools (e.g., BYU-Idaho, Weber State University, Southern Utah University, and Dixie State University) are trained for independent use of the instrument. The graduate and undergraduate research students using the instrument include male and female students (~60:40 ratio), domestic and international students (~50:50 ratio), and students from underrepresented groups in chemistry (~10%).

The 500 MHz NMR instrument supports the research of the USDA Poisonous Plant Research Laboratory near USU. The results of their ongoing studies are directly relevant to agriculture and ranching in the State of Utah, and more broadly in the Western US.
